DT Article
TI Studies on Lethrinitrema Lim & Justine, 2011 (Monogenea:
   Dactylogyridae), with the description of two new species, a key to the
   genus and a phylogenetic analysis based on rDNA sequences.
AU Sun, Yuan
   Li, Min
   Yang, Tingbao (lssytb@mail.sysu.edu.cn) 
SO Systematic Parasitology
VL 88
IS 2
PS 119-139
PD Jun 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 26
AB Six species of Lethrinitrema Lim & Justine, 2011, including two new
   taxa, are described from the gills of Lethrinus nebulosus (ForsskAyenl)
   from the South China Sea. Lethrinitrema nebulosum n. sp. differs from
   all other members of the genus in possessing a copulatory organ with a
   short, distally recurved tube, a cup-shaped base and a thin accessory
   piece, arising from distal end of tube, junction inconspicuous.
   Lethrinitrema zhanjiangense n. sp. can be distinguished from its
   congeners by possessing a copulatory organ with a C-shaped tube, a
   cup-shaped base and without accessory piece. Lethrinitrema
   grossecurvitubum (Li & Chen, 2005) n. comb. and Lethrinitrema
   austrosinense (Li & Chen, 2005) n. comb., previously included in
   Haliotrema Johnston & Tiegs, 1922, are transferred to Lethrinitrema and
   redescribed with additional details, including the intestinal caeca that
   unite posterior to gonads and continue posteriorly as two diverticula,
   and the elongate tubular distal end of each haptoral reservoir
   bifurcating prior to entering a superficial lateral groove on each side
   of the ventral anchor. The sclerotised parts of two unidentified species
   of Lethrinitrema are also described. Lethrinitrema sp. 1 differs from
   the other Lethrinitrema spp. in possessing a male copulatory organ
   consisting of a short tapered tube with a robust cup-shaped base and in
   lacking accessory piece. Lethrinitrema sp. 2 differs from its congeners
   in possessing a copulatory organ comprised of a short slender tube and
   without accessory piece, delicate ventral and dorsal bars, and poorly
   developed outer roots of the anchors. Sequences of partial 28S rDNA
   (domains D1-D2) and complete 18S rDNA for 27 dactylogyrids including
   five species of Lethrinitrema, i.e. Lethrinitrema fleti (Young, 1968)
   Lim & Justine, 2011, L. nebulosum, L. zhanjiangense, L. grossecurvitubum
   and Lethrinitrema sp. 1 were used to assess the monophyly of
   Lethrinitrema which was supported by high bootstrap values.

   510275, China, China.
EM lssytb@mail.sysu.edu.cn
OI Li, Min/0000-0002-5551-0134

AN ZOOR15010053414
PM 24832185
DT Article
TI Pseudobacciger cheneyae n. sp (Digenea: Gymnophalloidea) from Weber's
   chromis (Chromis weberi Fowler & Bean) (Perciformes: Pomacentridae) at
   Lizard Island, Great Barrier Reef, Australia.
AU Sun, Derek (derek.sun@uqconnect.edu.au) 
   Bray, Rodney A.
   Yong, Russell Q-Y
   Cutmore, Scott C.
   Cribb, Thomas H.
SO Systematic Parasitology
VL 88
IS 2
PS 141-152
PD Jun 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 13
AB A new species of digenean, Pseudobacciger cheneyae n. sp., is described
   from the intestines of Weber's chromis (Chromis weberi Fowler & Bean)
   from off Lizard Island, Great Barrier Reef, Australia. This species
   differs from the three described species of Pseudobacciger Nahhas &
   Cable, 1964 (P. cablei Madhavi, 1975, P. harengulae Yamaguti, 1938 and
   P. manteri Nahhas & Cable, 1964) in combinations of the size of the
   suckers and the length of the caeca. The host of the present species is
   a perciform (Family Pomacentridae) which contrasts with previous records
   of the genus which are almost exclusively from clupeiform fishes. The
   genus Pseudobacciger is presently recognised within the family
   Faustulidae (Poche, 1926) but phylogenetic analyses of 28S and ITS2 rDNA
   show that the new species bears no relationship to species of four other
   faustulid genera (Antorchis Linton, 1911, Bacciger Nicoll, 1924,
   Paradiscogaster Yamaguti, 1934 and Trigonocryptus Martin, 1958) but that
   instead it is nested within the Gymnophalloidea (Odhner, 1905) as sister
   to the Tandanicolidae (Johnston, 1927). This result suggests that the
   Faustulidae is polyphyletic.
C1 Sun, Derek; Univ Queensland, Sch Biol Sci, St Lucia, Qld, 4072,
   Australia, Australia.
EM derek.sun@uqconnect.edu.au
RI Sun, Derek/AAG-9911-2020; Cutmore, Scott C/B-7385-2012; Cribb,
   Thomas/C-4449-2008
OI Cutmore, Scott C/0000-0002-5648-3684; Cribb, Thomas/0000-0003-1092-9705;
   Yong, Russell Qi-Yung/0000-0003-2211-1468; Sun,
   Derek/0000-0002-8370-8287

   Pseudobacciger cheneyae [Piscean hosts / Chromis weberi / New parasite

   piscean host].

DT Article
TI Meggittina numida n. sp (Cyclophyllidea: Catenotaeniidae), a parasite of
   the Shaw's jird Meriones shawi (Duvernoy) (Rodentia: Gerbillinae) in
   Tunisia.
AU Jrijer, Jamel
   Neifar, Lassad (lassad.neifar@fss.rnu.tn) 
SO Systematic Parasitology
VL 88
IS 2
PS 167-174
PD Jun 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Meggittina numida n. sp. (Cyclophyllidea: Catenotaeniidae:
   Skrjabinotaeniinae) is described from the small intestine of the Shaw's
   jird Meriones shawi (Duvernoy) (Rodentia, Muridae, Gerbillinae) trapped
   in central Tunisia. The new species can be distinguished from the four
   other members of Meggittina Lynsdale, 1953 by the high number of
   proglottids (8-25 vs max. 6) and by the elongated strobila (8.2-60 mm in
   length vs max. 5.6 mm). M numida n. sp. further differs from M.
   cricetomydis (Hockley, 1961) in the direction of gravid proglottids;
   from M. baeri Lynsdale, 1953 in having narrower and much longer
   strobila; from M. aegyptiaca (Wolfgang, 1956) in the greater number of
   testes and the larger cirrus-sac; and from M. gerbilli in the position
   of the genital pore. The diagnosis of Meggittina is amended in order to
   include the most specific features of M. numida n. sp. as follows:
   strobila consisting of a small scolex, wide neck and one to twenty-five
   proglottids. This is the first species of Meggittina described from
   Tunisia. The taxonomic relationships of Meggittina spp. are discussed in
   the light of the description of the new species.
C1 Neifar, Lassad; Univ Sfax, Fac Sci Sfax, BP 1171, Sfax, 3038, Tunisia,
   Tunisia.
EM lassad.neifar@fss.rnu.tn
SC Zoology; Parasitology
SN 0165-5752
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Parasites diseases and
   disorders; Parasites; Helminth parasites; Hosts; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Africa
DE Meggittina numida [Mammalian hosts / Meriones shawi / New parasite
   species] [Tunisia /  / New species from mammalian host]. 
   Meriones shawi [Cestode parasites / Meggittina numida / New parasite
   species] [Tunisia /  / New platyhelminth parasite species].

DT Article
TI Coccidia of New World psittaciform birds (Aves: Psittaciformes): Eimeria
   ararae n. sp (Apicomplexa: Eimeriidae) from the blue-and-yellow macaw
   Ara ararauna (Linnaeus).
AU Lopes, Bruno do Bomfim
   Berto, Bruno Pereira (bertobp@ufrrj.br) 
   de Carvalho Balthazar, Lianna Maria
   Coelho, Cleide Domingues
   Neves, Daniel Medeiros
   Gomes Lopes, Carlos Wilson
SO Systematic Parasitology
VL 88
IS 2
PS 175-180
PD Jun 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 11
AB In the New World, the avian order Psittaciformes comprises 142 species,
   yet to date only 3 (2%) of the species have been examined for Coccidia,
   and from these only four species of Eimeria Schneider, 1875 have been
   described. In this study, a new coccidian species (Protozoa:
   Apicomplexa: Eimeriidae) obtained from the blue-and-yellow macaw Ara
   ararauna (Linnaeus) is reported from Brazil. Oocysts of Eimeria ararae
   n. sp. are ovoidal, measure 28.7 x 20.2 [mu]m and have a smooth,
   bi-layered wall c.1.1 [mu]m thick. Both micropyle and oocyst residuum
   are absent, but polar granules are present. Sporocysts are ovoidal and
   measure 17.0 x 8.3 A[mu]m, with knob-like, prominent Stieda body and
   sporocyst residuum is composed of granules; sub-Stieda body is absent.
   Sporozoites are vermiform with one refractile body and a nucleus. This
   is the fifth description of an eimerid coccidian infecting a New World
   psittaciform bird.
C1 Berto, Bruno Pereira; UFRRJ, Dept Biol Anim, BR-465 Km 7, Seropedica,
   RJ, BR-23897970 BC, Brazil, Brazil.
EM bertobp@ufrrj.br
RI Berto, Bruno P/N-3788-2013
OI Berto, Bruno P/0000-0002-1072-5254

   America

   species] [Brazil /  / New protozoan parasite species]. 
   Eimeria ararae [Avian hosts / Ara ararauna / New parasite species]
   [Brazil /  / New species from avian host].

PM 24832189
DT Article
TI A new species of Eimeria Schneider, 1875 (Apicomplexa: Eimeriidae) from
   the dusky rice rat Melanomys caliginosus (Tomes) (Mammalia: Rodentia) in
   Costa Rica.
AU Chinchilla, Misael
   Valerio, Idalia
   Sanchez, Ronald
   Gonzalez, Antonieta
   Duszynski, Donald W. (eimeria@unm.edu) 
SO Systematic Parasitology
VL 88
IS 2
PS 181-184
PD Jun 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB We collected faecal samples from 24 dusky rice rats, Melanomys
   caliginosus (Tomes) (Rodentia: Cricetidae: Sigmodontinae), in a
   Biological Reserve in Costa Rica, and found three (12.5%) to be infected
   with a species of Eimeria Schneider, 1875, which we describe here as
   new. Sporulated oocysts of Eimeria caliginosa n. sp. are almost
   spheroidal and measure 16-21 x 17-20 (mean 19.6 x 18.2) [mu]m;
   micropyle, oocyst residuum and polar granule are absent. Sporocysts are
   ovoidal, 9-13 x 6-8 (mean 11.2 x 6.7) [mu]m, with small Stieda and
   sub-Stieda bodies present, but a para-Stieda body is absent; the
   sporocyst residuum is a compact mass of c.11-15 granules, c.5 [mu]m
   wide. Sporozoites are crescent-shaped, 5-8 x 2-3 (mean 6.8 x 2.4) [mu]m.
   This is the third species of Eimeria described from the genus Melanomys
   Thomas.
C1 Duszynski, Donald W.; Univ New Mexico, Dept Biol, Albuquerque, NM,
   87131, USA, USA.
EM eimeria@unm.edu

SN 0165-5752

   Parasites; Hosts; Land zones; Neotropical region; Central America

   parasite species] [Costa Rica /  / New species from mammalian host]. 
   Melanomys caliginosus [Protozoan parasites / Eimeria caliginosa / New
   parasite species] [Costa Rica /  / New protozoan parasite species]. 
TN Chordates; Mammals; Protozoans; Rodents; Vertebrates

   Melanomys caliginosus (Mammalia), p. 182; Parasite].

PM 24832190
DT Article
TI Description of two species of Peniculus von Nordmann, 1832 (Copepoda:
   Siphonostomatoida: Pennellidae) parasitic on commercial fishes from
   Korea, including a new species.
AU Moon, Seung Yong (parmcourt@empas.com) 
   Choi, Seung Ho
SO Systematic Parasitology
VL 88
IS 2
PS 185-193
PD Jun 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Two pennellids of the genus Peniculus von Nordmann, 1832 (Copepoda:
   Siphonostomatoida: Pennellidae), including a new species, are described
   based on adult post-metamorphosis female specimens collected from
   commercially important fishes off Chuja Island, Korea. Peniculus
   quadratus n. sp. was collected from the surface of the mouth palate of
   the surfperch Neoditrema ransonnetii Steindachner (Perciformes:
   Embiotocidae). The new species can be differentiated from its congeners
   by a combination of the following features: the shape of the
   cephalothorax is relatively quadrangular, the fourth pedigerous somite
   is incorporated into the anterior end of trunk, and the trunk is
   bottle-shaped, narrowing slightly towards anterior extremity. Peniculus
   fistula von Nordmann, 1832 was collected from the dorsal fin and body
   surface of the pearl-spot chromis Chromis notata (Temminck & Schlegel)
   (Perciformes: Embiotocidae). A close comparison of the specimens of P.
   fistula collected from Korea with the original description revealed some
   differences in the shape of the cephalothorax and the length/width ratio
   of the trunk. These discrepancies are considered to represent
   intraspecific variation or observational errors. The finding of P.
   fistula represents not only a new record from the Northwest Pacific but
   also from a new host.
C1 Moon, Seung Yong; Natl Fisheries Res & Dev Inst, Fisheries & Ocean
   Informat Div, Busan, 619705, South Korea, South Korea.
EM parmcourt@empas.com

SN 0165-5752

   Parasites; Hosts; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean

   parasite systematics] [North Pacific / South Korea, Chuja Island / ].

   parasite species] [North Pacific / South Korea / New crustacean parasite
   species]. 
   Peniculus fistula [Piscean hosts / Chromis notata / New record;
   systematics] [North Pacific / South Korea, Chuja Island / ]. 
   Peniculus quadratus [Piscean hosts / Neoditrema ransonnetii / New
   parasite species] [North Pacific / South Korea / New species from
   piscean host].

PM 25134892
DT Article
TI Epidemiology of blood parasitic infections in the urban rat population
   in peninsular Malaysia.
AU Alias, S.N.
   Sahimin, N.
   Edah, M.A.
   Mohd-Zain, S.N. (nsheena@um.edu.my) 
SO Tropical Biomedicine
VL 31
IS 2
PS 230-240
PD Jun 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 1
U2 13
AB A total of 719 wild rats were captured from four localities representing
   the west (Kuala Lumpur), east (Kuantan), north (Georgetown) and south
   (Malacca) to determine the diversity of blood protozoan from the urban
   wild rat population in peninsular Malaysia. Five rat species were
   recovered with Rattus rattus diardii being the most dominant species,
   followed by Rattus norvegicus, Rattus exulans, Rattus annandalei and
   Rattus argentiventer. Two blood protozoan species were found infecting
   the rodent population namely, Plasmodium sp. (42.1%) and Trypanosoma
   lewisi (25.0%). This study reports the presence of Plasmodium sp. for
   the first time in the rodent population in Malaysia. Two main intrinsic
   factors were identified affecting the parasitic infections. Trypanosoma
   lewisi infections were influenced by host age and sex with infections
   observed higher in male and juvenile rats meanwhile Plasmodium sp.
   infections were observed almost similar in both sexes. However,
   infections were higher in sub-adult rats.
C1 Mohd-Zain, S.N.; Univ Malaya, Inst Biol Sci, Kuala Lumpur, 50603,
   Malaysia, Malaysia.
EM nsheena@um.edu.my

PM 25134903
DT Article
TI The blow fly, Chrysomya megacephala, and the house fly, Musca domestica,
   as mechanical vectors of pathogenic bacteria in Northeast Thailand.
AU Chaiwong, T. (tarinee.4004@gmail.com) 
   Srivoramas, T.
   Sueabsamran, P.
   Sukontason, K.
   Sanford, M.R.
   Sukontason, K.L.
SO Tropical Biomedicine
VL 31
IS 2
PS 336-346
PD Jun 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 27
AB The Oriental latrine fly, Chrysomya megacephala (Fabricius) (Diptera:
   Calliphoridae) and the house fly, Musca domestica L., (Diptera:
   Muscidae) are synanthropic flies which are adapted to live in close
   association with human habitations, thereby making them likely
   mechanical vectors of several pathogens to humans. There were two main
   aims of this study. The first aim was to determine the prevalence of
   these two fly species from five types of human habitations including:
   fresh-food markets, garbage piles, restaurants, school cafeterias and
   paddy fields, in the Muang Ubon Ratchathani and Warinchamrap districts
   of Ubon Ratchathani province of Northeast Thailand. Flies collection
   were conducted monthly from September 2010-October 2011 using a
   reconstructable funnel trap, containing 1 day-tainted beef offal as
   bait. A total of 7 750 flies (6 401 C. megacephala and 1 349 M.
   domestica) were collected. The second aim was to examine the potential
   of these flies to carry pathogenic bacteria. Bacteria were isolated from
   994 individual flies collected using a sweep net (555 C. megacephala and
   439 M. domestica). A total of 15 bacterial genera were isolated from the
   external surfaces, comprising ten genera of gram-negative bacteria and
   five gram-positive bacteria. The most common bacteria isolated from both
   species were coagulase-negative staphylococci, followed by Streptococcus
   group D non-enterococci. Human pathogenic enteric bacteria isolated were
   Salmonella sp., Shigella sp., Escherichia coli O157:H7, Salmonella
   typhi, Bacillus sp., and Enterococcus sp., of which S. typhi is the
   first report of isolation from these fly species. Other human pathogens
   included Staphylococcus aureus and Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Not only were
   the number of C. megacephala positive for bacteria significantly higher
   than for M. domestica, but they were also carrying [approximately]11-12
   times greater bacterial load than M. domestica. These data suggest that
   both fly species should be considered potential mechanical vectors of
   bacterial pathogens associated with human habitations year-round in this
   region of Northeast Thailand.
C1 Chaiwong, T.; Ubon Ratchathani Univ, Coll Med & Publ Hlth, Warinchamrap,
   Ubon Ratchathani, 34190, Thailand, Thailand.
EM tarinee.4004@gmail.com
RI Sanford, Michelle/C-9575-2011
OI Sanford, Michelle/0000-0001-6212-4023; L. Sukontason,
   Kabkaew/0000-0002-4820-290X; Sukontason, Kom/0000-0002-2424-956X
SC Parasitology; Zoology; Infectious Diseases; Environmental Sciences
   &Ecology
SN 0127-5720
BD Parasites diseases and disorders; Hosts; Transmission; Habitat; Man made
   habitat; Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Chrysomya megacephala; Musca domestica [Human hosts /  / prevalence]
   [Transmission of bacteria / Bacillus / ] [ / Enterococcus / ] [ /
   Escherichia / ] [ / Pseudomonas / ] [ / Salmonella typhi / New record] [
   / Salmonella / ] [ / Shigella / ] [ / Staphylococcus / ] [ /
   Streptococcus / ] [Urban habitat /  / ] [Thailand / Ubon Ratchathani / ]
   [ / Ubon Ratchathani Province / ].

TI PYRGOTID FLIES ASSIGNED TO APYRGOTA. II. NEW SYNONYMS IN EUPYRGOTA
   (SUBGENUS TAENIOMASTIX) (DIPTERA, PYRGOTIDAE), WITH KEY TO SUBGENERA AND
   SPECIES.
AU Korneyev, V.A. (valery.korneyev@gmail.com) 
SO Vestnik Zoologii
VL 48
IS 3
PS 211-220
PD Jun 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The synonymy of Taeniomastix Enderlein, 1942, syn. n. (type species:
   Taeniomastix sumatrana Enderlein, 1942) and Eupyrgota Coquillett. 1898
   is established. The subgeneric rank of Taeniomastix is proposed; the
   subgenus corresponds the spinifemur group of species sensu Korneyev
   (2006), with minor additions to its diagnosis. Four species from the
   Oriental (and partly Palaearctic), and two from Afrotropical Regions are
   included: E. formosana (Hennig, 1938), comb. n. (Apyrgota formosana), E.
   griseipennis (Hendel, 1933), comb. n. (Adapsilia griseipennis) (=
   Taeniomastix sumatrana Enderlein, 1942, syn. n.), E. pictiventris
   (Hendel, 1914) (Apyrgota) (= Adapsilia facialis Hendel, 1933, syn. n., =
   E. tigrina Kim et Han, 2000 syn. n.), E. saegeri (Vanschuytbroeck,
   1963); E. spinifemur (Hendel, 1934), and E. unicolor (Hendel, 1914),
   comb. n. (Apyrgota spinifemur); illustrated diagnoses of the transferred
   species are given. Keys to subgenera of Eupyrgota and species of the
   subgenus Taeniomastix are provided.

DT Article
TI Five new aquatic dance flies of the genus Hemerodromia Meigen (Diptera:
   Empididae: Hemerodromiinae) from Puerto Rico.
AU Harper, P.P. (harper@videotron.ca) 
   Masteller, E.C.
SO Canadian Entomologist
VL 146
IS 3
PS 241-247
PD Jun 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Systematic emergence trapping in two streams in the Luquillo Mountains
   Experimental Rainforest in Puerto Rico from 1989 to 1992 produced five
   new species of aquatic dance flies (Diptera: Empididae:
   Hemerodromiinae). They are described and illustrated as Hemerodromia
   marci Masteller new species, Hemerodromia melissa Masteller new species,
   Hemerodromia oncilla Masteller new species, Hemerodromia prieta Harper
   new species, and Hemerodromia simonis Harper new species.
C1 Harper, P.P.; Univ Montreal, Dept Sci Biol, CP 6128,Succursale Ctr
   Ville, Montreal, PQ, H3C 3J7, Canada, Canada.
EM harper@videotron.ca
SC Zoology
SN 0008-347X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones;
   Neotropical region; Central America; West Indies
DE Hemerodromia [Puerto Rico /  / Key to species]. 
   Hemerodromia marci; Hemerodromia melissa; Hemerodromia oncilla;

DT Article
TI Patagonicola: a new genus of xeromelissine bee from Argentina
   (Hymenoptera: Apoidea: Colletidae).
AU Packer, Laurence (xeromelissa@mail.com) 
SO Canadian Entomologist
VL 146
IS 3
PS 248-270
PD Jun 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Patagonicola Packer new genus is described for two species of
   xeromelissine bee (Hymenoptera: Colletidae) from Patagonian Argentina.
   One species, P. graveli Packer new species is described; the second
   species, P. aenigma (Packer) new combination, originally placed in
   Chilicola Spinola, 1851 subgenus Chilioediscelis Toro and Moldenke,
   1979, is designated as the type species. The new genus is superficially
   most similar to Xenochilicola Toro and Moldenke, 1979 but possesses none
   of the derived characteristics that were originally used to define that
   genus. Results of a phylogenetic analysis, based upon 114 morphological
   characters, are presented and suggest that the new genus is the sister
   clade to (Geodiscelis Michener and Rozen, 1999 + Xeromelissa Cockerell,
   1926). An illustrated key is provided for the genera of Xeromelissinae
   and for the two species of Patagonicola.

DT Article
TI Testing species limits of Eurytomidae (Hymenoptera) associated with
   galls induced by Diplolepis (Hymenoptera: Cynipidae) in Canada using an
   integrative approach.
AU Zhang, Y. Miles (yuanmeng.zhang@gmail.com) 
   Gates, Michael W.
   Shorthouse, Joseph D.
SO Canadian Entomologist
VL 146
IS 3
PS 321-334
PD Jun 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 2
U2 25
AB Studies of insect host-parasitoid relationships are often confounded by
   the difficulties associated with species delimitation in taxonomically
   challenging groups. Eurytomidae (Hymenoptera) are common parasitoids
   associated with galls induced by Cynipidae (Hymenoptera) and are
   difficult to identify due to their small size, morphological
   conservatism, and unreliable published host records. This study tests
   the species limits of eurytomids associated with galls induced by
   Diplolepis Geoffroy (Hymenoptera: Cynipidae) in Canada using an
   integrative taxonomy approach including adult morphology, the
   mitochondrial gene cytochrome c oxidase I, host records, and
   geographical range. Incongruences between morphological and molecular
   data were found within the Eurytoma discordans Bugbee complex, as
   Eurytoma discordans, Eurytoma acuta Bugbee, and Eurytoma Calcarea Bugbee
   were shown to be new synonyms. The results also revealed the presence of
   cryptic species within Eurytoma spongiosa Bugbee. Furthermore, issues
   that have impeded ecological and biological studies of eurytomids
   associated with rose galls such as host specificity and sex association
   were resolved using DNA barcodes, providing new insights into the
   evolutionary history of this difficult group.
C1 Zhang, Y. Miles; Univ Manitoba, Dept Entomol, Winnipeg, MB, R3T 2N2,
   Canada, Canada.

PM 24856523
DT Article
TI Bats as Reservoir Hosts of Human Bacterial Pathogen, Bartonella
   mayotimonensis.
AU Veikkolainen, Ville
   Vesterinen, Eero J.
   Lilley, Thomas M.
   Pulliainen, Arto T. (arto.pulliainen@helsinki.fi) 
SO Emerging Infectious Diseases
VL 20
IS 6
PS 960-967
PD Jun 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 21
AB A plethora of pathogenic viruses colonize bats. However, bat bacterial
   flora and its zoonotic threat remain ill defined. In a study initially
   conducted as a quantitative metagenomic analysis of the fecal bacterial
   flora of the Daubenton's bat in Finland, we unexpectedly detected DNA of
   several hemotrophic and ectoparasite-transmitted bacterial genera,
   including Bartonella. Bartonella spp. also were either detected or
   isolated from the peripheral blood of Daubenton's, northern, and
   whiskered bats and were detected in the ectoparasites of Daubenton's,
   northern, and Brandt's bats. The blood isolates belong to the
   Candidatus-status species B. mayotimonensis, a recently identified
   etiologic agent of endocarditis in humans, and a new Bartonella species
   (B. naantaliensis sp. nov.). Phylogenetic analysis of bat-colonizing
   Bartonella spp. throughout the world demonstrates a distinct B.
   mayotimonensis cluster in the Northern Hemisphere. The findings of this
   field study highlight bats as potent reservoirs of human bacterial
   pathogens.
C1 Pulliainen, Arto T.; Univ Helsinki, Dept Biosci, POB 56 Viikinkaari
   9,Bioctr 1, Helsinki, FI-00790, Finland, Finland.
EM arto.pulliainen@helsinki.fi
RI Lilley, Thomas/F-2236-2015; Vesterinen, Eero/I-6638-2012; Vesterinen,
   Eero J./Q-9527-2019
OI Lilley, Thomas/0000-0001-5864-4958; Vesterinen,
   Eero/0000-0003-3665-5802; Vesterinen, Eero J./0000-0003-3665-5802;
   Pulliainen, Arto Tapio/0000-0002-9361-8963

TI THE FIRST DAMSELFLY (INSECTA: ODONATA, HEMIPHLEBIIDAE) RECORDED FROM THE
   TURONIAN OF ISRAEL.
AU Vassilenko, D.V. (lab@palaeoentomolog.ru) 
SO Far Eastern Entomologist
VL 278
PS 1-7
PD Jun 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The damselfly Pantelusa krassilovi Vassilenko, gen. et sp. n. of the
   family Hemiphlebiidae is described from the Turonian of Israel (Gerofit
   locality, Ora Formation) from a single fossil wing. It is the first
   odonate known from this locality. The new genus is considered close to
   Cretaceous representatives of the family, especially the genus
   Electrohemzphlebia Lak et al., 2009, known from the Albian amber of
   France. The possibility is discussed that some endophytic ovipositions
   known from Gerofit belong to similar small damselflies.

TI A NEW FOSSIL GENUS OF OSMYLIDAE (NEUROPTERA) FROM THE EARLY CRETACEOUS
   OF BAISSA, TRANSBAIKALIA.
AU Makarkin, V.N. (vnmakarkin@mail.ru) 
SO Far Eastern Entomologist
VL 278
PS 8-12
PD Jun 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Kempynosmylus zherikhini gen. et sp. n. (Neuroptera: Osmylidae) is
   described from the Early Cretaceous of the Baissa locality (Russia:
   Transbaikalia). The genus is considered a member of the subfamily
   Kempyninae. Its main distinguishing feature is the very long AA1 (with
   >=3 branches). The forewing of the new genus further differs from that
   of Cretosmylus (the only other genus of the family known from that
   locality) by M forked approximately at level of termination of AA2,
   longer AA1, distinct color pattern, and larger size.

DT Article
TI Mechanisms of propagule release in the carnivorous sponge Asbestopluma
   occidentalis.
AU Chu, Jackson W.F. (jwfchu@uvic.ca) 
   Reiswig, Henry M.
SO Invertebrate Biology
VL 133
IS 2
PS 109-120
PD Jun 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 1
U2 24
AB Carnivorous sponges characteristically inhabit the deep sea, so
   extensive observations of the biology of living specimens are rare. We
   report on newly discovered shallow-water (<30m depth) populations of the
   carnivorous sponge Asbestopluma occidentalis and on observations of
   living adults and larvae from this unique group of sponges. In the
   Salish Sea, British Columbia, Canada, populations of A. occidentalis
   exist at depths as shallow as 18m, where they co-occur with
   hexactinellid sponges. Adults with and without embryos (n=127) were
   collected and easily maintained in the laboratory for several months,
   allowing continuous examination of live specimens. Parent sponges
   naturally disassociated their tissue, facilitating larval release and
   dispersal. Dispersed larvae had actively beating cilia, but no swimming
   was observed. Larvae settled and attached from several hours to several
   days post-release. After larval release, parent sponges reaggregated
   their disassociated bodies into spherical balls of apparently
   undifferentiated tissue, which could also disperse and settle. Sexually
   mature adults were sampled in the field from August to November, with a
   high proportion of adults containing mature embryos in late November.
   High-resolution photography and electron microscopy verified that adults
   were covered with anisochelae spicules, and used these to capture
   nauplii of Artemia sp. under experimental conditions; however,
   time-lapse photography showed that some captured prey could free
   themselves with vigorous swimming. The occurrence of abundant
   shallow-water populations of A. occidentalis in the Salish Sea provides
   a rare opportunity to study the evolution and ecology of carnivory in
   the Porifera.
C1 Chu, Jackson W.F.; Univ Victoria, Dept Biol, Victoria, BC, V6W 3N5,
   Canada, Canada.
EM jwfchu@uvic.ca
OI Chu, Jackson/0000-0002-7776-9446
SC Zoology; Nutrition &Dietetics; Reproductive Biology; Developmental
   Biology; Entomology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 1077-8306

   development; Development; Metamorphosis; Locomotion; Abiotic factors;
   Physical factors; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Asbestopluma occidentalis [Food capture / Prey capture / ] [Reproduction
   / Reproductive biology / ] [Life cycle / Life history / ] [Larval
   development /  / ] [Larval settlement / Larval release & settlement / ]
   [Swimming /  / ] [Depth /  / ] [North Pacific / Canada, British
   Columbia, Salish Sea / ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Sponges
ST Animalia, Porifera, Demospongiae
OR Asbestopluma occidentalis (Demospongiae).

TI Four new species of Chimarra Stephens (Trichoptera: Philopotamoidea:
   Philopotamidae) from Indian Himalaya.
AU Pandher, Manpreet Singh (mpandher.iari@gmail.com) 
   Saini, Malkiat Singh

SO Journal of Asia-Pacific Entomology
VL 17
IS 2
PS 183-189
PD Jun 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Four new species are added to the philopotamid fauna of India. The newly
   described species under Chimarra Stephens are Chimarra barnardi sp. nov.
   and C padami sp. nov. (both from Arunachal Pradesh), C bidenta sp. nov.
   from Uttarakhand and C quadrata sp. nov. from Sikkim. These species are
   distinguishable from each other as well as from previously known allied
   species by consistent variation in the structure of inferior appendages,
   tergite X and the phallic apparatus of males. (C) 2013 Korean Society of
   Applied Entomology, Taiwan Entomological Society and Malaysian Plant
   Protection Society. Published by Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

DT Article
TI Salinity Effects on Phragmites Decomposition Dynamics Among the Hudson
   River's Freshwater Tidal Wetlands.
AU Connolly, Craig T.
   Sobczak, William V.
   Findlay, Stuart E.G. (cconnolly@whrc.org) 
SO Wetlands
VL 34
IS 3
PS 575-582
PD Jun 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 95
AB Sea level rise due to climate change will expose Hudson River tidal
   marshes to chronic shifts in salinity, thus altering habitat conditions
   and biogeochemical processes. Increased salt intrusion may affect
   macroinvertebrate and microbial communities that are important in the
   decomposition of a dominant, invasive plant species Phragmites
   australis. We hypothesized that increased salinity intrusion will
   negatively affect macroinvertebrate and microbial litter breakdown
   processes. Field and laboratory experiments were conducted to test the
   effect of salinity on Phragmites decomposition. Leaf packets were
   incubated among tidal wetlands along a salinity gradient and used to
   compare microbial respiration, fungal biomass, and mass loss. In
   addition, salinity tolerance of a freshwater isopod (Caecidotea sp.) and
   heterotrophic microbes were examined using laboratory bioassays.
   Salinity negatively affected isopod survivorship and microbial activity
   in controlled laboratory experiments; however, salinity did not
   significantly account for in situ variation in Phragmites mass loss,
   microbial respiration, and fungal biomass among wetlands. Future studies
   need to include litter from additional wetland species and consider
   alternative controls on decomposition (e.g., variation in temperature or
   inorganic nutrients) in order to best forecast the long-term impact of
   sea-level rise and salinity increases among tidal freshwater wetlands.
C1 Findlay, Stuart E.G.; Cary Inst Ecosyst Studies, 2801 Sharon Turnpike,
   Millbrook, NY, 12545, USA, USA.
EM cconnolly@whrc.org
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology
SN 0277-5212
BD Ecology; Habitat; Abiotic factors; Chemical factors; Land zones;
   Nearctic region; North America; USA
DE Macroinvertebrata [Biological breakdown / Litter breakdown / ]
   [Semiaquatic habitat / Freshwater tidal wetlands / ] [Salinity /  / ]
   [New York / Hudson River Estuary / ]. 
TN Invertebrates
ST Animalia
OR Macroinvertebrata (Animalia).

AN ZOOR15109055865
DT Article
TI [What identification sessions can deliver in terms of new data: news
   from the beach at Maasvlakte 2.]
FT Wat determinatiesessies aan nieuwe gegevens kunnen opleveren: nieuws van
   het strand van Maasvlakte 2.
AU Mol, Dick (dickmol@telfort.nl) 
   Langeveld, Bram
SO Afzettingen Werkgroep voor Tertiaire en Kwartaire Geologie
VL 35
IS 2
PS 40-59
PD Jun 2014
PY 2014
LA Dutch
U1 0
U2 0
AB Maasvlakte 2 is an artificial westerly extension of the port of
   Rotterdam (the Netherlands), having been created from 240 million m3
   suction-dredged, coarse fluvial sediments from the Eurogeul area. These
   deposits are very rich in fossils of mammals and molluscs. Many private
   collectors collect from the Maasvlakte 2 beach. Mainly on the basis of
   some visits we made to these collectors, we here present a number of
   first records from this important locality. These are: Sus strozzii
   Forsyth Major, 1881, Mammuthus meridionalis (Nesti, 1825), Aloes
   latifrons (Johnson, 1874), Desmana thermalis Kormos, 1930, post-cranial
   material of Trogontherium cuvieri Fischer, 1809 and Desmana sp., molars
   of Ovibos moschatus (Zimmermann, 1780) and internal moulds of the
   freshwater snail Pfanorbarius corneu.s (Linnaeus, 1758). Based on the
   material studied, it is concluded that Maasvlakte 2 is exceptionally
   rich in fossils of Early and Middle Pleistocene age. This is most likely
   related to the great depth at which these sands were dredged. Thus,
   Maasvlakte 2 currently is the most important Pleistocene locality in the
   Netherlands, offering a wealth of new data on older Pleistocenefaunas
   from the Eurogeul area.
C1 Mol, Dick; Gudumholm 41, Hoofddorp, NL-2133 HG, Netherlands,
   Netherlands.
EM dickmol@telfort.nl
SC Zoology; Paleontology; Anatomy &Morphology; Environmental Sciences
   &Ecology
SN 0926-9347
BD Skeletal and supporting structures; Ecology; Fossilization; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Caenozoic;
   Quaternary
DE Alces latifrons; Desmana thermalis; Mammuthus meridionalis; Ovibos

DT Article
TI A new site of the Late Pleistocene theriofauna in the estuaries of the
   Bija river (South Minusinsk depression).
AU Malikov, D.G. (knight_1991@mail.ru) 
SO Amurskii Zoologicheskii Zhurnal
VL 6
IS 2
PS 111-116
PD Jun 2014
PY 2014
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new site of fossil mammals was discovered on the territory of
   Ust-Abakan district of the Khakass Republic, near the village Mokhovo
   (54[degree]56' N, 89[degree]46' E). The Mokhovo site is related to
   deposits of the Bija river. 5 species of large mammals were identified
   in the site: Bison priscus, Equus sp., Cervus elaphus, Saiga sp. H
   Capreolus capreolus. The finding of saiga and bison bones indicates the
   Late Pleistocene age of this site. The remains of an indeterminate small
   horse were also found.

   36, Tomsk, 634050, Russia, Russia.

DT Article
TI TWO NEW SPECIES OF THE GENUS LAIMYDORUS SIDDIQI, 1969 (NEMATODA,
   DORYLAIMIDA) FROM SMALL FRESHWATER BODIES OF VIETNAM.
AU Gagarin, V.G. (gagarin@ibiw.yaroslavl.ru) 
   Gusakov, V.A.
SO Amurskii Zoologicheskii Zhurnal
VL 6
IS 2
PS 117-124
PD Jun 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Two new species of free-living nematodes of the genus Laimydorus (L.
   gigas sp. nov. and L. tenuis sp. nov.), found in the sediments of small
   freshwater bodies in Vietnam, are described and illustrated. Laimydorus
   gigas sp. nov. is similar to L. distinctus Dey, Baqri, 1986 and L.
   elephas Andrassy, 1988. From the former species it differs in the longer
   tail in females, the shorter spicules and greater number of supplements
   in males. From L. elephas it differs in the thinner cuticle, thinner
   body, comparatively longer odontostyle and comparatively longer
   prerectum in females. Laimydorus tenuis sp. nov. is similar to L.
   merogaster (Steiner, 1916) and L. pinguis Andrassy, 1988. From the
   former species it differs in the thinner cuticle, thinner body, shorter
   odontostyle, shorter spicules and smaller number of supplements in
   males. From L. pinguis it differs in the thinner body, shorter tail in
   females, another position of vulva and comparatively longer prerectum in
   females.
C1 Gagarin, V.G.; Russian Acad Sci, Inst Biol Inland Waters, Borok,
   Yaroslavl Prov, 152742, Russia, Russia.
EM gagarin@ibiw.yaroslavl.ru

   Grigorievich/A-8438-2017
OI Gusakov, Vladimir A./0000-0002-9657-5049;

   region; Eurasia; Asia

TI TAXONOMIC NOTES ON LISPE (DIPTERA, MUSCIDAE). PARTS 1-9.
AU Vikhrev, N.E. (nikita6510@ya.ru) 
SO Amurskii Zoologicheskii Zhurnal
VL 6
IS 2
PS 147-170
PD Jun 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The world fauna of the Lispe leucospila group, L. tentaculata group, L.
   nivalis group, L. scalaris group, L. nana species complex, L. kowarzi
   species complex, L. desjardinsii group and L. longicollis group are
   considered. Five new species L. medvedevi sp. nov., L. tomkovichi sp.
   nov., L. martirei sp. nov., L. triangularis sp. nov. and L. dmitryi sp.
   nov.; one subspecies L. fulvitarsus asiatica ssp. nov. and hitherto
   unknown males of Lispe nubilipennis Loew, 1873 and Lispe flavipes Stein,
   1913 are described. Eight new synonymies are proposed: Lispe leucospila
   (Wiedemann, 1830) = Lispe eidsvoldica Malloch, 1925, syn. nov.; Lispe
   irvingi Curran, 1937 = Lispe mapaiensis Paterson, 1953, syn. nov. =
   Lispe andrewi Paterson, 1953, syn. nov.; Lispe pectinipes Becker, 1903 =
   Lispe paraspila Zielke, 1972, syn. nov.; Lispe tentaculata (De Geer,
   1776) = Lispe alpinicola Zhong, Wu & Fan, 1981 syn. nov.; L. scalaris
   scalaris Loew, 1847 = Lispe scalaris ssp. maroccana Canzoneri &
   Meneghini, 1966, syn. nov.; Lispe Latreille, 1796 = Lispacoenosia
   Snyder, 1949, syn. nov.; Lispe fulvitarsus (Snyder, 1949) comb. nov. =
   Lispe asetopleura Vikhrev, 2012 syn. nov. The identification keys for
   considered species groups, species complexes and proposed here L.
   tentaculata supergroup are given.

TI NEW LITHOSIINAE (LEPIDOPTERA, ARCTIIDAE: LITHOSIINAE) SPECIES COLLECTED
   BY A. SCHINTLMEISTER IN INDONESIA.
AU Dubatolov, V.V. (vvdubat@mail.ru) 
   Bucsek, K.

VL 6
IS 2
PS 176-181
PD Jun 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Four new Lithosiinae species and a new genus are described from
   Indonesia. Holotypes of new species are deposited in the Institute of
   Systematics and Ecology of Animals (Novosibirsk, Russia). They are:
   Macotasa sumatrana Dubatolov et Bucsek, sp. nov. and Lyclene diehli
   Dubatolov et Bucsek, sp. nov. from Sumatra, Pseudeilema ceramica

   schintlmeisteri Dubatolov et Bucsek, sp. nov. and Lyclene puncakica
   Dubatolov et Bucsek, sp. nov. from Sulawesi.

DT Article
TI [MAMMALS OF THE QUATERNARY OF PUERTO SANTA ROSA, DEPARTMENT OF SAN
   PEDRO, PARAGUAY.]
FT MAMIFEROS DEL CUATERNARIO DE PUERTO SANTA ROSA, DEPARTAMENTO DE SAN
   PEDRO, PARAGUAY.
AU Rios Diaz, Sergio D. (sergiord40@gmail.com) 
   Luna, Carlos A.
   Souberlich, Ricardo
   Aguilera, Paula
   de Campos Cervera, Ana M. Gadea
   Arana, Ana Godoy
SO Boletin del Museo Nacional de Historia Natural del Paraguay
VL 18
IS 1
PS 67-76
PD Jun 2014
PY 2014
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new fossiliferous locality, called Puerto Santa Rosa - which emerges
   along the margins of the Paraguay River, at San Pedro Department,
   Paraguay- is described in this contribution. The collected material has
   been determined as Megatherium cf. M. americanum (Pilosa), Toxodon sp.
   (Notoungulata), cf. Notiomastodon (Proboscidea) and Hemiauchenia sp.
   (Artiodactyla), which allowed us to reffer this faunistic assemblage
   into a Pleistocene-Early Holocene age, agreeing with the geological data
   available for the studied sector. The above mentioned material
   constitues the first fossil record of mammals from San Pedro Department,
   in Central Paraguay.
C1 Rios Diaz, Sergio D.; Secretaria Nacl Cultura, Direcc Gen Bienes & Serv
   Culturales, Asuncion, Paraguay, Paraguay.
EM sergiord40@gmail.com

   periods; Caenozoic

   San Pedro, Puerto Santa Rosa / ] [Quaternary /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Mammals; Vertebrates

DT Article
TI Revision of the genus Galinthias Stal, 1877 (Mantodea, Galinthiadidae).
FT Revision du genre Galinthias Stal, 1877 (Mantodea, Galinthiadidae).
AU Roy, Roger (rroy@mnhn.fr) 
   Stiewe, Martin B.D.
SO Bulletin de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 119
IS 2
PS 199-215
PD Jun 2014
PY 2014
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB This paper is a genus revision of Galinthias stal, 1877, which also
   contains the newly described species G. rhomboidalis n. sp. The genus
   Galinthias is widely distributed south of the sub-Sahara line and is
   also present in some countries in the Middle East with the species G.
   philbyi (Uvarov, 1936), n. comb. With the newly described species G.
   rhomboidalis n. sp. and the new combination of G. philbyi, there are now
   five species recorded within the genus Galinthias: G. amoena (Saussure,
   1871), G. meruensis Sjostedt, 1909, G. rhomboidalis n. sp., G.
   occcidentalis Beier, 1930, and G. philbyi (Uvarov, 1936). G. philbyi was
   formerly sorted under the genus Arabistania Kocak & Kemal, 2008, which
   had replaced the genus Attalia Uvarov, 1936, due to homonymy. The status
   of Attalia has been discussed by Beier (1937) and Kaltenbach (1982) with
   regards to whether it should belong to the genus Galinthias. Extensive
   research for this paper, including first-time genital examinations of
   Arabistania, has produced clear evidence that Arabistania belongs to the
   genus Galinthias. It also became clear that many of the Galinthias
   specimens in collections have been wrongly identified by previous
   scientists. For this reason the authors felt it necessary to re-examine
   most of the specimens and especially their genitals, which had been
   largely ignored in the past. Furthermore, comparisons of several
   Galinthias type-specimens showed that the species Galinthias usambarica
   Sjostedt, 1909, is a new synonym of G. amoena (Saussure, 1871), whilst
   in the past it had been treated as a synonym of G. meruensis. In this
   paper, a new family Galinthiadidae is established, which will include
   the closest relative of Galinthias, the African genera Pseudoharpax
   Saussure, 1870, and Congoharpax La Greca, 1954. This is supported by the
   phylogenetic relationship seen in the cladistics-sequence-data phylogram
   which is pictured in the paper of Svenson & Whiting (2009). For the
   first time a comprehensive distribution map has been compiled, showing
   many new localities for all known species. A historical overview of the
   genus Galinthias is provided, as well as a key to the species in French
   and English.
C1 Roy, Roger; Museum Natl Hist Nat, CP 50,57 Rue Cuvier, Paris, F-75231,
   France, France.
EM rroy@mnhn.fr
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Reproductive Biology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 0037-928X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Combination; Synonymy;
   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Key; General morphology; Reproduction;
   Reproductive system; Evolution; Zoogeography; Land zones; Afrotropical
   region; Africa
DE Galinthias [General morphology /  / new record; systematics;
   distribution map] [Genitalia / Genital morphology / ] [Phylogeny /
   Phylogenetic relationships / ] [Zoogeography /  / ] [Afrotropical region
   /  / Key to species] [ /  / biology; distribution]. 
   Galinthias rhomboidalis [Kenya /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Dictyoptera, Mantodea
OR Arabistania philbyi - (Uvarov 1936) (Mantodea): [Referred to,
   Galinthias, p. 211]. 
   Congoharpax - La Greca 1954 (Mantodea): [Referred to, Family
   Galinthiadidae, p. 201]. 
   Galinthiadidae - Giglio-Tos 1919 (Mantodea): [Type species, Galinthias
   Stal 1877, p. 201; Status, P. 201, Cited by author as new family].

   Asturias, Northern Spain (Carabidae, Trechinae, Trechini).
FT Una nueva especie hipogea del genero Trechus del Macizo del Sueve,
   Asturias, norte de Espana (Carabidae, Trechinae, Trechini).
AU Toribio, Marcos (toribio.bembidion@gmail.com) 
SO Bulletin de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 119
IS 2
PS 229-233
PD Jun 2014
PY 2014
LA French
U1 0
U2 1
AB Trechus pilonensis n. sp. is decribed. The species was collected in a
   MSS (Mesovoid Shallow Substratum) in the Sueve Massif (Eastern
   Asturias). Individual characters of the new species, and in particular
   the structure of the male genitalia, are highlighted. It is compared
   with the species of the Cantabrian Mountain that, by their morphological
   characteristics, are closely related.

PT J
AN ZOOR15109055954
DT Article
TI The French species of Myzininae: taxonomic and biological problems
   (Hymenoptera, Tiphiidae).
FT Les especes francaises de Myzininae : problemes taxonomiques et
   biologiques (Hymenoptera, Tiphiidae).
AU Bitsch, Jacques (colette.bitsch@orange.fr) 
   Grouet, Gerard
   Savina, Henri
SO Bulletin de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 119
IS 2
PS 257-274
PD Jun 2014
PY 2014
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB This paper on the French Myzininae, ectoparasitoid wasps of subterranean
   beetle larvae, is based on observations in Southern France
   (Languedoc-Roussillon) and on the study of several collections. The
   taxonomic study of the Myzininae is made difficult, due to a high sexual
   dimorphism and to the slight differences between the described taxa. Our
   observations lead us to assume that four species, assigned to two
   genera, probably occur in France: Meria cylindrica (Fabricius, 1793), M
   tripunctata (Rossi, 1790), M lineata Sichel, 1859, and Poecilotiphia
   rousselii (Guerin-Meneville, 1838). We consider Meria dorsalis
   (Fabricius, 1804) as a junior synonym of M cylindrica. The rare females
   M lineata are characterized by the reduction of the wings to short
   stumps, while the macropterous males are difficult to separate from
   those of other related species. Some information on the biology and
   distribution of these species is provided and discussed.
C1 Bitsch, Jacques; 30 Rue Lac Doo, Toulouse, F-31500, France, France.
EM colette.bitsch@orange.fr
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Reproductive Biology
SN 0037-928X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; General morphology; Reproduction;
   Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe
DE Myzininae [General morphology /  / systematics] [Sex differences /  / ]
   [France /  / biology; distribution]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Aculeata,
   Scolioidea, Tiphiidae
OR Meria cylindrica - (Fabricius 1793) (Tiphiidae): [Syn nov, Meria
   dorsalis (Fabricius 1804), p. 261]. 
   Myzininae (Tiphiidae). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15109055954
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR15403010123
DT Article
TI New nomenclatural changes for 2014: I. The genus Rhytiphora
   Audinet-Serville, 1835 (Coleoptera, Cerambycidae, Lamiinae).
AU Tavakilian, Gerard (tava@mnhn.fr) 
   Nearns, Eugenio H.
SO Cahiers Magellanes-NS
VL 15
PS 99-108
PD Jun 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Recent generic changes in the Australian fauna of Lamiinae lead us to
   rename 27 species of the genus Rhytiphora Audinet-Serville, 1835. We
   also point out the 206 resulting new combinations of species now
   included in this huge genus (412 species), half of which belongs to the
   Australian fauna and was already recombined. We completed the synonymy
   at the subgeneric level for Indonesia, Malaysia, Papua-New-Guinea and
   Philippines. For a complete updated list of the genus Rhytiphora, please
   open the database Titan at: http://lully.snvjussieu.filtitan/
C1 Tavakilian, Gerard; Museum Natl Hist Nat, Dept Systemat & Evolut, 45 Rue
   Buffon, Paris, F-75005, France, France.
EM tava@mnhn.fr

PT J
AN ZOOR15111069442
DT Article
TI Contribution to the Hyles centralasiae-siehei species group. On the
   biology, ecology, distribution and geographic variability of H. siehei
   (PUNGELER, 1903) and reinterpretation of Hyles svetlana SHOVKOON, 2010
   (Lepidoptera: Sphingidae).
FT Beitrag zur Hyles centralasiae-siehei-Artengruppe. Zur Biologie,
   Okologie, Verbreitung und geographischen Variabilitat von H. siehei
   (PUNGELER, 1903) und Reinterpretation von Hyles svetlana SHOVKOON, 2010
   (Lepidoptera: Sphingidae).
AU De Freina, Josef J. (defreina.j@online.de) 
   Geck, Martin
SO Entomologische Zeitschrift
VL 124
IS 2
PS 67-95
PD Jun 2014
PY 2014
LA German
U1 0
U2 2
AB The Hyles centralasiae-siehei-species group is examined on the basis of
   extensive sampling. This complex appears to be clusters of partially
   isolated populations with distinctive characteristics and in the process
   of speciating, their colonies have become localised. Food habits and
   adaptation to different ecological features have obviously created
   changes in the genome and generated distinct species, as in H.
   centralasiae (STAUDINGER, 1887), H. siehei (PUNGELER, 1903) and H.
   svetlana SHOVKOON, 2010, stat. nov. Due to inaccurate or contradictiory
   statements (and due to the lack of historic data), H. siehei has been
   wrongly classified over a long period of time as a synonym or subspecies
   of H. centralasiae. As its status is satisfactorily resolved, many
   difficult questions, regarding biology, ecology and distribution of
   these two closely related species, have arisen. Therefore, in this paper
   previously data in literature are examined, validated and if clearly
   evident, assigned with H. siehei. Informations, especially on H. siehei,
   are partially interwoven with inapplicable statements. So we adapt false
   maid claims about distribution, phenology and host plant to the reality
   and supplement in this paper new biogeographical and biological
   knowledge about H. siehei, obtained as a result of intensive fieldwork
   and several breeding programmes in Turkey by us over a period of more
   than ten years. The focus of this contribution gives priority of the
   species H. siehei and H. svetlana, originally described as subspecies of
   H. siehei. Observations are made on the ecology, morphology, phenology
   and dissemination of the two taxa and the proposition that they are in
   fact two species is substantiated. Genetic research confirms a small
   distance in mtDNA between the two and draws attention to an evolutionary
   young, but distinct separation of the two taxa. On this basis,
   evidentiary data and distribution information of the two species are
   presented and morphological features for the differentiation are
   revealed. The larval biology, pupation, the live specimen and the
   genitalia of H. siehei are provided and illustrated in colour and
   diagnostically compared with those of H. svetlana and H. centralasiae.
   Territorial claims and distribution of H. siehei and H. svetlana, both
   steppe inhabitants, are commented on. Preliminary distribution pattern
   are discussed and revised. The host plant spectra are qualified. The
   natural host plants of H. siehei are confined to Asphodelus spp.
   (Asphodelaceae), those of H. svetlana are limited to Eremurus
   inderiensis (Liliaceae) whereas H. centralasiae, spread from the Iranian
   Kopet Dagh through Central Asia to Mongolia, develops on Eremurus spp.
   and Drimia spp. (Asparagaceae). Within the range of these three species,
   specimens and potentially even individuals occur that appear to have
   transitional features to the Hyles euphorbiae (LINNAEUS, 1758)- and
   Hyles hippophaes (ESPER, (17931))-groups, in particular and most
   clearly, Hyles euphorbiae conspicua (ROTHSCHILD & JORDAN, 1903) and
   Hyles robertsi (BUTLER, 1880). Therefore the occurrence of hybrid
   populations in these regions, whose possibility is repeatedly
   demonstrated by several succeeding laboratory breeding, is very likely.
C1 De Freina, Josef J.; Eduard Schmid Str 10, Munich, D-81541, Germany,
   Germany.
EM defreina.j@online.de
SC Nutrition &Dietetics; Zoology; Developmental Biology; Evolutionary
   Biology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 0013-8843
BD Systematics; Taxonomy; Status; Nutrition; Diet; Life cycle and
   development; Evolution; Variation; Ecology; Zoogeography; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia
DE Hyles centralasiae-siehei species group [Food plants /  / systematics]
   [Life cycle and development /  / ] [Morphological variation /  / ]
   [Ecology /  / ] [Zoogeography /  / ] [Palaearctic region /  / biology;
   distribution] [Turkey /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Sphingoidea, Sphingidae
OR Hyles centralasiae-siehei species group (Sphingidae). 
   Hyles siehei - (Puengeler 1903) (Sphingidae): [Status, P. 67]. 
   Hyles siehei svetlana - Shovkoon 2010 (Sphingidae): [Raised to, Hyles
   svetlana, p. 86]. 
   Hyles svetlana - Shovkoon 2010 (Sphingidae): [Raised from, Hyles siehei
   svetlana, p. 86]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15111069442
DA 2020-09-17

AN ZOOR15111069443
DT Article
TI Anomaloninae from Israel and Palestine with description of a new species
   of Anomalon (Hymenoptera: Ichneumonidae).
FT Anomaloninae aus Israel und Palastina mit Beschreibung einer neuen
   Anomalon-Art (Hymenoptera: Ichneumonidae).
AU Schnee, Heinz (Heinz.Schnee@web.de) 
SO Entomologische Zeitschrift
VL 124
IS 2
PS 97-107
PD Jun 2014
PY 2014
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB The 23 species of Anomaloninae occurring in Israel and Palestine are
   revised. Anomalon almagorense sp. nov. is described, and a key is given
   for the Anomalon species hitherto known from Israel. A further eleven
   species are new for the Israeli fauna, among them the poorly known
   species Anomalon (recte Agrypon) andalusiacum STROBL, 1904. A lectotype
   is selected for it and the species is redescribed. Erigorgus lanator
   AUBERT, 1989 proved to be a new synonym of Heteropelma signatum
   (GRAVENHORST, 1829) and Romanella maracandica MEYER, 1935 is a new
   synonym of Atrometoides winkleri FAHRINGER, 1922.
C1 Schnee, Heinz; Birkenweg 18, Markkleeberg, D-04416, Germany, Germany.
EM Heinz.Schnee@web.de

   Synonymy; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia

   Anomalon almagorense [Israel /  / New species]. 
   Anomaloninae [Israel /  / Biology; distribution; faunal list; new
   record; systematics].

   Ichneumonoidea, Ichneumonidae

   100]. 
   Anomalon almagorense (Ichneumonidae): [Sp nov, Israel, P. 97].

   Romanella maracandica Meyer 1935, p. 103]. 
   Heteropelma signatum - (Gravenhorst 1829) (Ichneumonidae): [Syn nov,
   Erigorgus lanator Aubert 1989, p. 104].

DT Article
TI First record of the Australian genus Platyobria TAYLOR, 1987 from Europe
   and P. biemani sp nov as a potential pest of Eucalyptus (Myrtaceae)
   (Hemiptera: Psylloidea).
AU Burckhardt, Daniel (daniel.burckhardt@bs.ch) 
   Queiroz, Dalva L.
   Malenovsky, Igor
SO Entomologische Zeitschrift
VL 124
IS 2
PS 109-112
PD Jun 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Platyobria biemani sp. nov. (Aphalaridae, Spondyliaspidinae) is
   described from the island of Lesbos (Greece) based on a series of adult
   specimens which were collected on a long-leaved Eucalyptus species. This
   is a likely host as immatures of three of the nine previously known
   species of Platyobria TAYLOR, 1987 develop on young succulent terminal
   branchlets or leaves of eucalypts. This is the first time that
   Platyobria is recorded from outside Australia from where the new species
   probably originates. Whereas Platyobria species do not seem to affect
   their hosts significantly in Australia, there is a potential that in a
   new environment lacking specific parasitoids, P. biemani sp. nov. may
   become a pest of eucalypts.
C1 Burckhardt, Daniel; Nat Hist Museum, Augustinergasse 2, Basel, CH-4001,
   Switzerland, Switzerland.
EM daniel.burckhardt@bs.ch
RI Malenovsky, Igor/F-3969-2019
OI Malenovsky, Igor/0000-0001-8840-2263

SN 0013-8843

   Hosts; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe

   [Greece /  / New species from plant host].

   (Plant), p. 110; Parasite].

DT Article
TI Danish harvestmen - a fauna on the increase.
FT Danske mejere - en fauna i vaekst.
AU Enghoff, Henrik (henghoff@snm.ku.dk) 
   Pedersen, Jan
   Toft, Soren
SO Entomologiske Meddelelser
VL 82
IS 1
PS 1-12
PD Jun 2014
PY 2014
LA Danish
U1 0
U2 0
AB Since 1985 the number of harvestmen species recorded from Denmark has
   grown from 17 to 25. The new species and the year of their first Danish
   record are: Opilio canestrinii (Thorell, 1876) - 1985; Lacinius horridus
   (Panzer, 1794) - 1994; Odiellus spinosus (Bosc, 1792) - 2006;
   Dicranopalpus ramosus (Simon, 1909) - 2007; Leiobunum sp. A. - 2008;
   Paranemastoma quadripunctatum (Perty, 1833) - 2009; Nelima semproni
   Szalay, 1951 - 2012; Platybunus pinetorum (C.L. Koch, 1839) - 2013.
   Notes are given on the decline of Opilio parietinus (De Geer, 1778), O.
   saxatilis C.L. Koch, 1839, and Leiobunum tisciae Avram, 1968 (= L.
   rupestre auct.) in Denmark; and Nemastoma dentigerum Canestrini, 1873,
   N. bimaculatum (Fabricius, 1775), Lacinius dentiger (C.L. Koch, 1848),
   Leiobunum limbatum L. Koch, 1861, and Nelima doriae (Canestrini, 1871)
   are mentioned as candidates for future discoveries in Denmark.

DT Article
TI Faunistic study of Ichneumon wasps, (Hym., Ichneumonidae) from
   Mazandaran province, Iran.
AU Hooshyar, H. (hengame.hooshyar@yahoo.com) 
   Vafaei-Shoushtari, R.
   Barimani-Varandi, H.
SO Fasinamah-i tahqiqat-i hasharah-shinasi
VL 6
IS 2
PS 191-202
PD Sum 2014
PY 2014
LA Farsi
U1 0
U2 0
AB The fauna of Ichneumonidae was studied during 2011 to 2012 in the
   centeral area of Mazandaran province. In this study Malaise trap, Window
   trap, Yellow & White Pan trap, Light trap and Sweeping net were used for
   collecting. A total of 13 species belonging to 11 Genera and 8
   subfamilies were collected and identified. The identification were
   confirmed by Prof. Mehmet Faruk Gurbuz and Dr. Kees Zwakhals. The
   specimens were deposited at Agricultural and Natural Resources Research
   Center of Mazandaran, Sari and Entomology Department, Agricultural
   faculty of Arak University. Five species are new records for Iranian
   insect fauna which indicated by an asterisk. The following species were
   collected: Anomalon cruentatum (Geoffray, 1785) (Anomaloninae)
   Tromatobia oculatoria (Fabricius, 1798)* (Pimplinae) Liotryphon caudatus
   (Ratzeburg, 1848) (Pimplinae) Pimpla spuria (Gravenhorst, 1829)
   (Pimplinae) Clistopyga rufator (Holmgren, 1856) (Pimplinae) Tryphon
   atriceps (Stephens, 1835) (Tryphoninae) Syrphoctonus sp. (Thomson,
   1890)*(Diplazontinae) Lissonota clypeator (Gravenhorst, 1820)*
   (Banchinae) Lissonota fundator (Gravenhorst, 1820)* (Banchinae)
   Lissonota versicolor (Gravenhorst, 1820)* (Banchinae) Collyria coxator
   (Villers, 1789) (Collyrinae) Mesochorus sp. (Forster, 1869)
   (Mesochorinae) Brachycyrtus sp. (Townes, 1960) (Brachycyrtinae)

PT J
AN ZOOR15111074492
DT Article
TI The systematic position of Acanthalburnus microlepis (De Filippi, 1863)
   and contributions to the genus Acanthobrama (Cyprinidae: Leuciscinae) in
   Turkey.
AU Kucuk, Fahrettin (fahrettinkucuk@sdu.edu.tr) 
   Bektas, Yusuf
   Guclu, Salim Serkan
   Kaya, Cuneyt
SO Iranian Journal of Ichthyology
VL 1
IS 2
PS 96-105
PD Jun 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB In this study, the systematic position of Acanthalburnus microlepis from
   Kura and Aras basins is clarified and some notes on the taxonomy of the
   Acanthobrama species distributed in Turkey are given. Based on the
   morphological and osteological analyses, a high similarity between A.
   microlepis and Acanthobrama members is found. Some taxonomic information
   yielded from the examination of recent collections from Dicle (Tigris),
   Firat (Euphrates), Asi (Orontes), Ceyhan, Seyhan rivers and Berdan
   Stream near Tarsus is also included. Accordingly, Acanthobrama marmid is
   distributed only in Dicle-Firat system (presumably also in Sinnap Stream
   from Kuveik Drainage) and the populations from Asi, Seyhan and Berdan
   Stream (Tarsus) regarded as a separate subspecies as A. marmid orontis
   Berg, 1949 should be considered full species according to phylogenetic
   species concept and Ceyhan population represents a new species.
C1 Kucuk, Fahrettin; Suleyman Demirel Univ, Egirdir Fisheries Fac, Eastern
   Campus, Isparta, TR-32200, Turkey, Turkey.
EM fahrettinkucuk@sdu.edu.tr
OI Bektas, Yusuf/0000-0002-8367-9746
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology
SN 2383-1561; 2383-0964
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Diagnosis; Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy;
   Taxonomic position; General morphology; Skeletal and supporting
   structures; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia
DE Acanthobrama [General morphology /  / systematics] [Skeleton / Osteology
   / ] [Turkey /  / distribution]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Cypriniformes, Cyprinidae
OR Acanthalburnus microlepis - (De Filippi 1863) (Cyprinidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Acanthobrama, p. 100]. 
   Acanthobrama - Heckel 1843 (Cyprinidae): [Diagnostic characters of
   subordinate taxa, P. 103; Syn nov, Acanthalburnus Berg 1916, p. 100]. 
   Acanthobrama microlepis - De Filippi 1863 (Cyprinidae): [Referred to,
   Acanthalburnus, p. 100]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15111074492
DA 2020-09-17

DT Article
TI Two new distributional and host records for Spalangia Latreille
   parasitizing Drosophila sp on putrefied tender jack fruit (Artocarpus
   heterophyllus) from Kerala, India.
AU Sureshan, P.M. (pmsuresh43@yahoo.com) 
   Farsana, V.K. Raseena
SO Journal of Biological Control
VL 28
IS 2
PS 57-61
PD Jun 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The species Spalangia impunctata Howard is reported for the first time
   from India and Spalangia simplex Perkins reported for the first time
   from Kerala. Both the species are reared from the pupae of Drosophila
   sp. on putrefied tender Jack fruit, which form the first host records
   for the species. A checklist of the Indian species of Spalangia with
   host data is also provided.

PT J

DT Article
TI A Glimpse at Ethology in Latin America.
AU Spinelli, Oliveira E.
   Cantano, L.M.R.
   Baptista, T.
   Boere, V.
   Ferrari, H.R.
   Francescoli, G.
   Josens, R.
   Klein, W.
   Monticelli, P.F.
   Whitlock, K.
   Santos, W.F.
SO Revista de Etologia
VL 13
IS 1
PS 10-27
PD Jun 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The state of the art of Ethology in five Latin America countries is
   briefly presented here. The overall outlook regarding research
   laboratories and themes is promising: the community is numerous, active
   and there are topics addressing all aspects of animal behavior,
   especially in large countries like Brazil and Argentina. Ethology as an
   undergraduate discipline is generally a subcategory of Biology, being
   taught mainly at Zoology/Psychology/Ecology/Agriculture Courses and at
   Medical Veterinary Schools, often as an eligible discipline. Ethology as
   a formal major Graduate Program is rare and mainly restricted to Brazil.
   Regular Ethology meetings are held in Argentina, Brazil and Uruguay. In
   Chile and Venezuela there is a small but very active community. Studies
   of animal behavior are often carried out in other areas than Biology,
   and there is a clear overlap of interest regarding the major topics of
   Ethology. Behavioral ecology, conservation, management and animal
   welfare are a priority in most countries, probably reflecting a general
   concern regarding endangered species and habitats of the continent. Here
   we present information aiming to create a network that will increase
   collaborations among researchers working within the ethological
   framework in Latin America. The IV Simposio de Etologia na America
   Latina, entitled "Desarrollo de la Etologia en Latinoamerica: hacia un
   futuro regional ?" was held in November, 2013, as part of the XXXI
   Encontro Anual de Etologia (EAE), in Sao Paulo, SP, Brazil. The state of
   art of Animal Behavior in Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Uruguay and
   Venezuela were presented there and a set of six questions guided the
   presentations: 1) What are the main Ethology topics being studied in
   laboratories in your country? - 2) Are there undergraduate or graduate
   programs in the main universities? - 3) Is there an Animal Behavior
   Society? How interested is the community in establishing close ties
   among institutes or laboratories elsewhere in Latin America? - 4) Is
   there a site, a journal, a page on a social networking site for contact,
   communication and divulgation of original data? - 5) How active is the
   community regarding the wiliness to organize congresses, symposia,
   meetings, workshops, on-line courses regarding Ethology? - 6) Are there
   funding agencies to support exchange programs and research in Ethology?
   Additional data were collected from the last two EAE regarding
   researchers from Latin America that attended EAE meetings and a list of
   names and laboratories was compiled (see appendix). It should be
   emphasized that the compilation of information presented here is far
   from complete. It represents a brief overview of the current status of
   Ethology in only five Latin American countries, and therefore it should
   be updated continuously with new data from the countries treated here as
   well as supplemented with data from other countries. Such a constantly
   updated list would facilitate the creation of networks that should
   increase collaborations among researchers working within the ethological
   framework in Latin America.
C1 Spinelli, Oliveira E.; USP, FFCLRP, Av Bandeirantes 3900, Ribeirao
   Preto, SP, BR-14040901 BC, Brazil, Brazil.
RI Monticelli, Patricia/A-8523-2013
OI Monticelli, Patricia/0000-0001-6765-4058
SC Zoology; Behavioral Sciences
SN 1517-2805
BD Behaviour; Land zones
DE Animalia [Behaviour / Ethological studies / Review] [Land zones / Latin
   America / ]. 
ST Animalia
OR Animalia. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15208048459
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR15208051697
DT Article
TI New Percichthyidae (Teleostei, Percoidei) from the early Pliocene of the
   Buenos Aires province (Argentina) and its biogeographical implications.
FT Nuevo Percichthyidae (Teleostei, Percoidei) del Plioceno temprano de la
   provincia de Buenos Aires (Argentina) y sus implicancias biogeograficas.
AU Agnolin, Federico L. (fedeagnolin@yahoo.com.ar) 
   Bogan, Sergio
   Tomassini, Rodrigo L.
   Manera, Teresa
SO Revista del Museo Argentino de Ciencias Naturales
VL 16
IS 1
PS 19-31
PD Jun 2014
PY 2014
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB The paleoichthyological record from the early Pliocene of Farola Monte
   Hermoso locality, southern Buenos Aires province (Argentina) is still
   patchy and biased. During such time span, this locality may be related
   to the Rio Colorado paleobasin, and consequently may have been related
   to the Austral Ichthyogeographical Region. In the present contribution
   we describe a new genus and species of a very large Percichthyidae,
   coming from fluvial deposits of the Monte Hermoso Formation. The new
   taxon constitutes the sister group of the genera Percichthys and
   Santosius. This finding, together with other previous
   paleoichthyological records, as well as phylogenetic and phylogeographic
   molecular analyses of living taxa, suggest the existence of an
   ichthyofaunistic turnover for the late Neogene in the Patagonian region.
   In this way, the current composition of the Patagonian ichthyofauna
   would be of recent age, possibly from the Pleistocene.
C1 Agnolin, Federico L.; Museo Argentino Ciencias Nat Bernardino Rivadavia,
   Lab Anat Comparada & Evoluc Vertebrados, Av Angel Gallardo 470, Buenos
   Aires, DF, RA-1405, Argentina, Argentina.
EM fedeagnolin@yahoo.com.ar
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 1514-5158

   Neotropical region; South America; Geological time periods; Caenozoic;
   Tertiary; Neogene
DE Pisces [Zoogeography / Biogeography / Significance of new taxon]
   [Argentina / Patagonian region / ] [Pliocene / Early Pliocene / ]. 
   Plesiopercichthys [Pliocene /  / New genus]. 
   Plesiopercichthys dimartinoi [Argentina /  / new species] [Pliocene /  /
   ].

   Perciformes, Percichthyidae

   Plesiopercichthys dimartinoi (Percichthyidae): [Sp nov, Argentina,
   Pliocene, P. 21; Fossil].

DT Article
TI On the genus Latonigena Simon (Araneae, Gnaphosidae): description of two
   new species, the female of L. santana, and new records.
AU Lopez Carrion, Nicolas (carrion.nico@gmail.com) 
   Grismado, Cristian J.
SO Revista del Museo Argentino de Ciencias Naturales
VL 16
IS 1
PS 81-88
PD Jun 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The taxonomy of the genus Latonigena Simon is updated after the study of
   the collection of the Museo Argentino de Ciencias Naturales (Buenos
   Aires). Two new species are described: L. pampa, n. sp., from Buenos
   Aires Province, Argentina, and L. pittieri, n. sp., from Aragua,
   Venezuela (the first record of a member of this genus from that
   country). Three species previously known from Brazil (L. turvo, L. lami,
   and L. santana) are newly reported from Argentina, and the female of the
   latter is here described for the first time. Zelotes zonatus (Holmberg)
   is considered nomen dubium.

   Rivadavia, Div Aracnol, Av Angel Gallardo 470,C1405DJR, Buenos Aires,
   DF, Argentina, Argentina.

DT Article
TI PHYLOGENETIC RELATIONSHIPS OF Calomys sorellus COMPLEX (RODENTIA:
   CRICETIDAE), WITH THE DESCRIPTION OF TWO NEW SPECIES.
AU Zeballos, Horacio (horaciozeballos@gmail.com) 
   Palma, R. Eduardo
   Marquet, Pablo A.
   Ceballos, Gerardo
SO Revista Mexicana de Mastozoologia Nueva Epoca
VL 4
IS 1
PS 1-23
PD Jun 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB We reviewed the phylogenetic relationships of forms assigned to Calomys
   sorellus based on the Cytochrome b gene sequences and morphological
   comparisons. We present the first description of the evolutionary
   relationships within the C. sorellus species complex. The results show a
   clade with species from lowlands of Eastern of Andes and other clade
   with Andean species which contains: C. musculinus, C. sorellus and C.
   lepidus which would be species complex. One of the new species occurs in
   the Atiquipa Lomas in the coastal desert of southern Peru, and other on
   the occidental slope of southern Peru in Arequipa and Moquegua. These
   new species are based upon considering their phenotypic characteristics
   (size, coloration, pelage), geographic distribution, and molecular
   phylogeny.
C1 Zeballos, Horacio; Pontificia Univ Catolica Peru, Inst Ciencias Nat Terr
   & Energias Renovables, Ave Univ 1801, Lima, 32, Peru, Peru.
EM horaciozeballos@gmail.com
OI Ceballos, Gerardo/0000-0001-8374-2656

   [Molecular genetics / Cytochrome b gene sequences / ] [Phylogeny /  / ].

DT Article
TI Contribution to the knowledge of Agromyzidae (Diptera: Muscomorpha) in
   Peru.
FT Contribucion al conocimiento de los Agromyzidae (Diptera: Muscomorpha)
   en el Peru.
AU Korytkowski, Cheslavo A. (cheslavok@gmail.com) 
SO Revista Peruana de Entomologia
VL 49
IS 1
PS 1-107
PD Jun 2014
PY 2014
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB Twelve genera were treated, Agromyza Fallen, Japanagromyza Sasakawa,
   Melanagromyza Hendel, Ophiomyia Braschnikov, Cerodontha Rondani,
   Amauromyza Hendel, Calycomyza Hendel, Phytobia Lioy, Phytoliriomyza
   Hendel, Liriomyza Mik Haplopeodes Steyskal and Phytomyza Fallen; a total
   of 77 species are reported for Peru, 45 of them are analyzed, reviewed,
   described and discussed based on external morphological characters and
   specially on male genitalic structures, checked out with other
   previously described for the region; 17 of them are new for the science;
   and 31 species were previously recorded by other authors for Peru. Key
   to genera and species are included. Nomenclatural names are dicussed,
   especially for the more common species; habits and host-plants are
   reported for most of them, based on collected material and specimens
   from national collections. Current names used for more common species
   are discussed, as well as the actual morphological terms used for
   Diptera taxonomy of Agromyzidae family. Methods to disect and
   preparations of male genitalia are described and drawed, for both,
   phallic and periphallic structures.
C1 Korytkowski, Cheslavo A.; Univ Panama, Programa Ctr Amer Postgrad
   Entomol, Panama City, Panama.

DT Article
TI A NEW CRYPTIC SPECIES OF GECKO OF THE GENUS Hemidactylus Oken, 1817
   (REPTILIA: GEKKONIDAE) FROM SOUTHERN INDIA.
AU Mirza, Zeeshan A. (zeeshanm@ncbs.res.in) 
   Sanap, Rajesh V.
SO Taprobanica
VL 6
IS 1
PS 12-20
PD Jun 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of gecko superficially resembling Hemidactylus maculatus
   is described from the southern Indian state of Tamil Nadu. Hemidactylus
   acanthopholis sp. nov. is a large sized Hemidactylus, SVL at least
   91.7mm. Dorsal scalation on trunk granular, intermixed with enlarged,
   fairly regularly arranged longitudinal rows of 18-20 trihedral,
   moderately keeled, striated tubercles of equal size on dorso-lateral
   aspect, 2-3 rows of tubercles on mid-dorsal smaller in size,
   approximately two dorsal granular scales wide. Two large rounded and one
   small internasal between nasals. Two pairs of postmentals, anterior pair
   is twice as long and wide as the posterior pair. Scales on ventral trunk
   arranged in 35-40 rows. Lamellae divided, 9, 11, 10, 10, 10 on manus,
   and 10, 12, 12, 12, 12 on pes respectively on digits I-V. Caudal
   pholidosis on dorsal aspect, consist of small, striated scales
   intermixed with large rounded un-keeled tubercles, scales sub-equal
   throughout and a series of large eight enlarged, moderately keeled and
   weakly striated and flattened tubercles in a whorl on each caudal
   segment. Femoral pores, 19-21 on each side separated medially by 13-14
   pore-less scales.
C1 Mirza, Zeeshan A.; Tata Inst Fundamental Res, Natl Ctr Biol Sci,
   Bangalore, Karnataka, 560065, India, India.
EM zeeshanm@ncbs.res.in
SC Zoology
SN 1800-427X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Eurasia; Asia; India

ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Lepidosauria, Squamata,
   Sauria, Gekkonidae
OR Hemidactylus acanthopholis (Gekkonidae): [Sp nov, Tamil Nadu, P. 13].

   Tenebrionidae) from Taiwan.
AU Ando, Kiyoshi
   Bremer, Hans J.
SO Japanese Journal of Systematic Entomology
VL 20

LA English

U2 1
AB Amarygmus antecedens sp. nov. and A. antecursor sp. nov. are described
   from Taiwan. Amarygmus curvus Marseul, 1876, so far known from Japan and
   S Korea, is newly recorded from Taiwan. Illustrations of the related
   Amarygmus-species in Taiwan are given.

DT Article
TI Description of a Male Cephalotheca of Myrmecolax sp (Strepsiptera:
   Myrmecolacidae) in a Camponotus sp (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) in
   Thailand.
AU Nakase, Yuta (yuta.nakase@gmail.com) 
   Kato, Makoto
   Kathirithamby, Jeyaraney
SO Japanese Journal of Systematic Entomology
VL 20
IS 1
PS 17-20
PD May 31 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB This is the first description of the cephalotheca (anterior part of
   puparium) of a male Myrmecolar sp. (Strepsiptera: Myrmecolacidae), which
   was found in a winged male of the nocturnal ant Camponotus sp.
   (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) from Thailand. The stylopized ant was found
   during day time high on a small tree in a tropical monsoon forest in
   Thailand. This record is significant as most other free-living male
   Myrmecolacidae are found in traps and hence lack host records.
C1 Nakase, Yuta; Natl Museum Nat & Sci, Dept Zool, 4-1-1 Amakubo, Tsukuba,
   Ibaraki, 3050005, Japan, Japan.
EM yuta.nakase@gmail.com

   disorders; Parasites; Insect parasites; Hosts; Insect hosts; Land zones;
   Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Camponotus [Strepsipteran parasites / Myrmecolax / New record; parasite
   systematics; male] [Thailand /  / ]. 
   Myrmecolax [Hymenopteran hosts / Camponotus / New record; systematics;
   male] [Thailand /  / ].

DT Article
TI Revision of the Genus Teleutaea Forster, 1869 from Japan (Hymenoptera:
   Ichneumonidae: Banchinae).
AU Watanabe, Kyohei
   Maeto, Kaoru
SO Japanese Journal of Systematic Entomology
VL 20
IS 1
PS 27-41
PD May 31 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Ten species of the genus Teleutaea Forster, 1869, are recognized from
   Japan. The status of T. nigricoxalis (Uchida, 1928) is restored from the
   synonym of T. sachalinensis Uchida, 1928, to the separate species. Three
   synonyms are newly established, i.e., T. corniculata Momoi, 1978 = T.
   striata (Gravenhorst, 1829), T. kasparyani Kuslitzky, 1979 = T. diminuta
   Momoi, 1978, and T. longiterebra Kuslitzky, 1973 = T. nigricoxalis.
   Distribution data and a key to Japanese species are provided.
C1 Watanabe, Kyohei; Kanagawa Prefectural Museum Nat Hist, Iriuda 499,
   Odawara, Kanagawa, 2500031, Japan, Japan.
SC Zoology
SN 1341-1160
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Description; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Key; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Teleutaea [Japan /  / Key to species] [ /  / New record; systematics]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Terebrantia,
   Ichneumonoidea, Ichneumonidae
OR Teleutaea - Foerster 1869 (Ichneumonidae): [Redescription, P. 27; Key to
   species, Japan, P. 28; New record]. 
   Teleutaea brischkei - (Holmgren 1860) (Ichneumonidae): [Redescription,
   P. 30]. 
   Teleutaea diminuta - Momoi 1978 (Ichneumonidae): [Redescription, P. 31;
   Syn nov, Teleutaea kasparyani Kuslitzky 1979, p. 31]. 
   Teleutaea minamikawai - Momoi 1963 (Ichneumonidae): [Redescription, P.
   32]. 
   Teleutaea mishae - Kuslitzky 1973 (Ichneumonidae): [Redescription, P.
   33]. 
   Teleutaea nigra - Momoi 1978 (Ichneumonidae): [Redescription, P. 34]. 
   Teleutaea nigricoxalis - (Uchida 1928) (Ichneumonidae): [Redescription,
   P. 35; Syn nov, Teleutaea longiterebra Kuslitzky 1973, p. 35; Removal
   from synonymy, With Teleutaea sachalinensis Uchida 1928, p. 35]. 
   Teleutaea orientalis - Kuslitzky 1973 (Ichneumonidae): [Redescription,
   P. 36]. 
   Teleutaea sachalinensis - Uchida 1928 (Ichneumonidae): [Redescription,
   P. 37; Removal from synonymy, Teleutaea nigricoxalis (Uchida 1928), p.
   35]. 
   Teleutaea striata - (Gravenhorst 1829) (Ichneumonidae): [Redescription,
   P. 38; Syn nov, Teleutaea corniculata Momoi 1978, p. 38]. 
   Teleutaea ussuriensis - (Golovisnin 1928) (Ichneumonidae):
   [Redescription, P. 39].

PT J
